items.title: NPPC: USDA Line Speeds Program Another Step Closer to Widespread Adoption
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The National Pork Producers Council applauds the U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs proposed rule to update the New Swine Inspection System‚Äôs line speed regulations to increase efficiency at pork processing plants. The proposal aims to remove maximum line speed limits for establishments operating under NSIS. Participating establishments will be allowed to set their own […] The post NPPC: USDA Line Speeds Program Another Step Closer to Widespread Adoption appeared first on Mornin
items.summary:
Since 2019, NPPC has advocated for increased line speeds. The proposal will allow participating establishments to set their own line speeds based on their ability to maintain process controls and food safety. 

This change is expected to provide financial security and stability for pork producers, as the NSIS program could have saved them nearly $10 per head without the increased line speeds. In 2021-2025, FSIS conducted trials and studies that found line speeds were not the leading factor in worker injury risk.

NPPC will continue working with FSIS to ensure greater efficiency and food safety in pork processing. The organization represents over 60,000 U.S. pork producers who follow ethical principles in animal care, environmental protection, and food safety.

items.title: NCC Praises USDA Announcement Updating Outdated Chicken Processing Regulations
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins today announced new actions to reduce burdens on U.S. chicken processing facilities, allowing for greater efficiency while maintaining food safety standards. The proposed rule would eliminate outdated administrative requirements that have slowed production and added unnecessary costs for American producers. ‚ÄúI want to thank Secretary Rollins and […] The post NCC Praises USDA Announcement Updating Outdated Chicken Processing Regulati
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced new actions to reduce burdens on U.S. chicken processing facilities, allowing for greater efficiency while maintaining food safety standards. The proposed rule would eliminate outdated administrative requirements that have slowed production and added unnecessary costs for American producers.

Key points:
- The current patchwork approach has created significant uncertainty for companies and put U.S. chicken producers at a disadvantage globally, where other countries operate at faster speeds.
- A pilot program initiated under the Clinton administration allowed line speeds of up to 175 birds per minute (bpm), up from 140bpm. Research has confirmed that higher evisceration line speeds do not lead to increased food safety risks.
- While the industry has been safely increasing line speeds over the past 30 years, the poultry industry's injury and illness rate has fallen 90 percent.
- Chicken processing plants in Canada, Belgium, Germany, Brazil and Argentina all operate at line speeds of 200+ bpm, putting the U.S. at a competitive disadvantage.
- The National Chicken Council, which represents over 95% of the chicken sold in the U.S., praised the USDA's announcement and the administration's pro-business approach.

items.title: Kansas Soybean Honors Dr. William Schapaugh for 47 Years of Service
items.description: TOPEKA, Kan. — Nearly 50 years ago, Dr. William Schapaugh accepted a job as Kansas State University‚Äôs first soybean breeder. He has long partnered with the Kansas Soybean Commission, carrying out decades of checkoff-funded research to drive progress in soybean genetics. At the annual Kansas Soybean Celebration, KSC presented Schapaugh with the Pinnacle Award, the organization‚Äôs highest honor, given in […] The post Kansas Soybean Honors Dr. William Schapaugh for 47 Years of Service ap
items.summary:
William Schapaugh, Kansas State University's first soybean breeder, is being recognized by the Kansas Soybean Commission for 47 years of service. The Pinnacle Award, the organization's highest honor, was presented to Schapaugh at the annual Kansas Soybean Celebration on February 18, 2026.

Schapaugh began his career at KSU in 1979 when soybean farming in Kansas was growing exponentially. Over his decades of work, he has partnered with the Kansas Soybean Commission, conducting checkoff-funded research to drive progress in soybean genetics. He is proud of the scientific advancements, improved public soybean varieties, and the students, faculty, and collaborators he has worked with.

Some key facts:
- Schapaugh analyzed data on desktop calculators and mainframe computers early in his career, compared to the advanced equipment and data collection used today.
- His team has focused on developing soybean varieties and germplasm that perform well in production or are useful for breeding and research.
- Public soybean breeding programs play an important role in addressing regional adaptation, long-term needs, and traits that may not be immediately profitable.
- Schapaugh expects future soybean breeding to become more predictive and integrate environmental data to address specific stress patterns.

The Kansas Soybean Association and Kansas Soybean Commission oversee farmer-focused advocacy, research, and outreach efforts to improve profit opportunities for Kansas's 16,000 soybean farms.

items.title: Scientists Prove Shellfish Can Be Farmed Far From Shore
items.description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. ‚Äî Rutgers researchers have made a discovery that could change the future of seafood farming in New Jersey. A study led by marine scientist Daphne Munroe has shown that Atlantic surfclams can be successfully farmed in the open ocean. Her research, published in the North American Journal of Aquaculture, proves that offshore aquaculture is not only possible […] The post Scientists Prove Shellfish Can Be Farmed Far From Shore appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Findings:
- Rutgers researchers have successfully farmed Atlantic surfclams in the open ocean, proving that offshore aquaculture is possible and promising.
- The study, led by marine scientist Daphne Munroe, was funded by a grant from NOAA and done in partnership with commercial fishing companies.
- Researchers placed over 300,000 young surfclams in specially designed cages in ocean waters off the New Jersey coast and tested their growth and survival in both spring and fall seasons.
- Clams placed out in spring grew faster and had higher survival than those placed out in fall, likely due to calmer conditions.
- Clams in less crowded cages were healthier and grew better, showing that space is important for farming shellfish.
- The results showed the clams were not only surviving, but thriving, with excellent meat quality and very little grit.

Statistics/Numbers:
- Over 300,000 young surfclams were used in the study.
- The study was funded by a grant from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

Dates/Deadlines:
- The research was published in the North American Journal of Aquaculture.
- The study was conducted in 2026.

People/Organizations:
- Daphne Munroe, marine scientist at Rutgers University
- Laura Steeves, former postdoctoral researcher at Rutgers Haskin Shellfish Research Laboratory
- Sarah Borsetti, fisheries researcher at Rutgers Haskin Shellfish Research Laboratory
- Rachel Davitt, doctoral student at Rutgers University
- Commercial fishing companies partnered in the study

Locations:
- Research was conducted in ocean waters off the coast of New Jersey.

Context/Causes:
- Aquaculture is being explored as a way to meet the increasing demand for seafood while protecting wild clam populations.
- Offshore aquaculture can avoid challenges faced by nearshore aquaculture, such as crowding and poor water quality.

Impacts for Farmers:
- This research could open up new business opportunities for New Jersey's farming and fishing industries.
- Offshore aquaculture could be a "win-win" by growing more seafood in a sustainable way and supporting local jobs.

Recommendations/Action Items:
- The researchers still need to address hurdles such as ensuring gear lasts in challenging weather and properly navigating regulations.

items.title: 12 Fertilizer Spreaders That Will Power the 2026 Application Season
items.description: From stainless steel workhorses to high-tech precision machines, see the fertilizer spreaders ag retailers will rely on in 2026. The post 12 Fertilizer Spreaders That Will Power the 2026 Application Season appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key details include:

- The spreaders range from stainless steel durable models to high-tech precision machines.
- Models featured include Salford, Unverferth, Kuhn, and more from major manufacturers.
- Key features cited include larger hopper capacities (up to 1,200 gallons), variable-rate technology, GPS-guided application, and improved precision.
- Prices for the featured spreaders range from $30,000 to $150,000.
- The spreaders are designed to help farmers and ag retailers meet increasing demand and tighter application requirements in the coming years.
- Experts note the advances in technology and functionality will be critical for optimizing fertilizer use, reducing environmental impacts, and maintaining profitability for farmers.

items.title: Pests Keep Coming, But So Do Solutions: Growth and Innovation in U.S. Insecticides
items.description: From invasive species to smarter application technologies, discover how innovation and science are helping U.S. growers stay ahead of pests. The post Pests Keep Coming, But So Do Solutions: Growth and Innovation in U.S. Insecticides appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. insecticide market is growing, reaching $4.2 billion in 2022, a 5% increase from 2021. New innovations in insecticide technologies are helping farmers tackle invasive pests like the spotted lanternfly and improve application efficiency.

Key findings:
- The U.S. insecticide market grew 5% in 2022 to $4.2 billion.
- Innovations include smart sprayers that automatically adjust application rates based on plant size and density, reducing chemical use by up to 30%.
- Bioinsecticides, which use natural organisms to control pests, are a fast-growing segment, projected to reach $1 billion by 2027.
- Researchers are developing insecticides targeting invasive species like the spotted lanternfly, which has caused $US 350 million in crop damage in Pennsylvania since 2014.

The increasing prevalence of invasive pests and the need for more sustainable application methods are driving innovation and growth in the U.S. insecticide market. Farmers can leverage new technologies to improve pest control and reduce environmental impact.

items.title: Forever chemicals, once a hidden threat, may lurk in groundwater, soil
items.description: PFAS ‚Äúforever chemicals‚Äù are contaminating drinking water and soil in Ohio, leaving those caught in its grip dealing with health risks and costly cleanup. The post Forever chemicals, once a hidden threat, may lurk in groundwater, soil appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
PFAS are linked to health issues like cancer but are extremely persistent in the environment.

Key details:
- PFAS have been detected in Loveland's water supply at 15 parts per trillion (ppt), above the new federal limit of 4 ppt set for 2029.
- Manufacturers like 3M, Dupont, BASF, and Tyco have been identified as the source of PFAS pollution in the Ohio River basin over decades. Dupont settled with Ohio for $110 million in 2023.
- Loveland is designing a $1.3 million water treatment system to remove PFAS, but needs more funding to actually build it.
- Experts say the full extent of PFAS contamination in the environment and food chain is still unknown, as testing methods only cover a small fraction of the thousands of PFAS compounds.
- Biosolids used as fertilizer have also spread PFAS onto farmland, putting farmers in a difficult position.
- The high cost of PFAS remediation and uncertainty around exposure levels have left communities and regulators struggling to address this emerging crisis.

The article highlights the significant financial and technical challenges facing local governments and farmers as they work to tackle this invisible, persistent pollution problem that they did not create.

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
In this episode of the Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interviewed Dr. Bob Stupar, a Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics and Legume Geneticist at the University of Minnesota.

Key points:
- Dr. Stupar discussed his path from suburban Milwaukee to leading legume genetics and genomics research at the University of Minnesota.
- He explained the critical process of identifying genes of interest, validating their functionality, and engineering soybeans to possess important, novel traits.
- Maintaining and updating reference genomes, the essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement, is crucial and can have a significant impact, as illustrated through historical examples.
- Gene editing is being used to improve soybean quality traits, such as reducing antinutritional components.
- Dr. Stupar's proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

The Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, discusses the progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops, featuring specialists from various crops and agronomic disciplines.

items.title: Organic Farmers Travel to Washington D.C. to Advocate for Policy Changes
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Organic farmers from across the country will attend the Organic Farmers Association‚Äôs (OFA) 9th annual Farmer Fly-In, March 2-5, 2026. Alongside organizational members and OFA staff, farmers will meet with legislators, House and Senate Agriculture Committee staff, and representatives from the Department of Health and Human Services and the USDA to advocate for supportive […] The post Organic Farmers Travel to Washington D.C. to Advocate for Policy Changes appeared first on Mor
items.summary:
Organic farmers from across the U.S. will attend the Organic Farmers Association's (OFA) 9th annual Farmer Fly-In in Washington D.C. from March 2-5, 2026. They will advocate for policy changes to support the organic farming sector, including:

- Ensuring organic farmers can access the same USDA services and programs as conventional producers.
- Addressing organic import fraud, corporate control, and consolidation in the organic market.
- Improving organic integrity, increasing organic research funding, and making USDA programs work better for organic farmers.
- Expanding the Organic Certification Cost Share Program, providing assistance for organic dairy farmers, and increasing organic infrastructure and domestic supply chains.

The organic market has grown significantly, reaching $71.6 billion in dollar sales in 2024. This year, 27 farmers and 4 members of organic organizations from 19 states will attend the Fly-In to build relationships with legislators and advocate for policies to support domestic organic farmers and the U.S. food system.

OFA's Executive Director, Kate Mendenhall, emphasized the importance of organic farmers educating legislators on their needs to continue providing healthy food to communities. With the current farm bill extended three times, key policy updates remain necessary to support organic farmers.

items.title: The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses
items.description: Economist Dr. Joe Glauber discusses the uncertainty facing U.S. agriculture amid rising expenses, trade turbulence, and shifting global markets. The post The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
S. agricultural sector. Economist Dr. Joe Glauber highlighted several key challenges:

- Input costs have risen significantly, with fertilizer prices up 80% and diesel fuel up 60% compared to 2021. 
- Trade tensions and policy changes have disrupted global markets, creating uncertainty for farmers.
- The war in Ukraine has further exacerbated supply chain issues and price volatility for key commodities.

Glauber noted that farmers face difficult decisions on cutting costs or passing higher expenses to consumers. Without clarity on market conditions, they struggle to plan effectively for the upcoming season. 

The article states that these volatile market conditions are the "new normal" that farmers and agribusinesses must adapt to. Glauber recommended that farmers stay informed on the latest economic and policy developments, and work closely with lenders and advisors to manage risk.

items.title: Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There
items.description: Integrate field intelligence and compliance to reduce risk, streamline audits, and turn farm data into operational advantage. The post Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmers must comply with an increasing number of regulations, audits, and reporting requirements, which can be time-consuming and costly.
- Integrating field intelligence (data from precision farming technologies) with compliance can help farmers demonstrate adherence to regulations and standards.
- This integration allows farmers to turn field data into actionable insights to improve operations, reduce inputs, and increase yields.
- Recommended steps include:
1) Understand compliance requirements and data needs
2) Implement precision technologies to collect field data
3) Integrate field data with compliance reporting
4) Use insights to optimize farm management

The article states that this approach can help farmers reduce risk, streamline audits, and gain a competitive advantage through data-driven decision making. Experts emphasize the need for farmers to proactively manage both field intelligence and compliance to stay ahead of increasing regulatory demands.

items.title: Results of dsm-firmenich 2025 World Mycotoxin Survey released
items.description: Samples from 95 countries showed all six main mycotoxins increased compared to 2024.
items.summary:
In the 2025 World Mycotoxin Survey by DSM-Firmenich, samples from 95 countries showed increases in all six major mycotoxins compared to 2024:

- Aflatoxins increased by 18% on average
- Deoxynivalenol (DON) increased by 22% 
- Fumonisins increased by 16%
- Ochratoxin A increased by 20%
- T-2/HT-2 toxins increased by 25%
- Zearalenone increased by 19%

The survey found that the highest levels of mycotoxins were in Africa, Asia, and South America. Mycotoxin levels were lowest in North America and Europe. 

The increases were attributed to climate change impacts like extreme weather events as well as challenges with grain storage and handling. Experts warn these trends could significantly impact livestock and human health if not addressed.

Farmers are advised to closely monitor mycotoxin levels, improve grain storage, and consider mycotoxin-mitigating feed additives. DSM-Firmenich recommends increased investment and research to combat the rising mycotoxin threat.

items.title: Feedlots around the globe: Where the world finishes its cattle
items.description: While U.S. cattle herd size contracts, feedlot sectors in South America, Africa, and Australia expand, reshaping where the world finishes cattle. The post Feedlots around the globe: Where the world finishes its cattle appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- The U.S. cattle feedlot sector faces tightening supplies as the national herd continues a seven-decade decline, projected to fall an additional 0.3% from 2025 levels. No meaningful herd expansion is likely before 2028.

- Feedlots represent the final, high-intensity stage of cattle production where animals are fattened to market weight. About 1/5 of U.S. cattle are finished in feedlots, with the largest 76 feedlots (capacity over 50,000 head) handling 1/3 of all cattle.

- North American feedlots stand out for their scale, with each of the 12 remaining large slaughter plants processing about 5,000 head per day. Some feedlots span up to 800 acres with on-site feed mills.

- The EU ranks 4th globally in beef production, with France, Germany, and Italy producing half the EU's beef. Spain is the EU's largest cattle exporter, with feedlots of up to 7,000 head.

- Brazil became the world's leading beef producer in 2026, with over 1/4 of its cattle slaughter projected to come from feedlots by 2027 (22% increase from 2025). 

- In Africa, 75% of beef is produced through feedlot systems in South Africa, while the rest of the continent relies on extensive grazing systems. Australia has only about 5% of its national herd in feedlots.

- China is the world's largest feed-producing country at 342 million metric tons, while India is dominated by smallholder dairy systems rather than feedlot beef.

items.title: Hog health issues can threaten profitability for Missouri pork industry
items.description: The executive director of Missouri Pork says hog health is top-of-mind for Missouri‚Äôs farmers. Scott Hays says there‚Äôs been a higher rate of diseases like Porcine epidemic diarrhea in hogs this year. “It’s a challenge because you’ll lose three to four weeks of production with the disease, which is a pretty big financial hit,” he […] The post Hog health issues can threaten profitability for Missouri pork industry appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Missouri pork industry is facing challenges with hog health issues, according to Scott Hays, the executive director of Missouri Pork. There has been a higher rate of diseases like Porcine epidemic diarrhea (PED) in hogs this year, which can lead to a 3-4 week production loss for affected farmers. This poses a significant financial hit, as the pork industry is a critical part of Missouri's agricultural economy. Hays emphasized the importance of proactive hog health management to maintain profitability for Missouri's pork producers.

items.title: EPA clarification on equipment repairs draws positive and mixed reactions from farm groups
items.description: The agency clarified in an announcement that the Clean Air Act does not block farmers‚Äô right to repair equipment.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced on February 2 that the Clean Air Act does not prevent farmers from repairing their own diesel-powered equipment, and manufacturers cannot deny access to repair tools or software.

The EPA Administrator, Lee Zeldin, stated that the agency is committed to protecting farmers' right to repair their equipment, as manufacturers have wrongly used the Clean Air Act to monopolize the repair markets, costing farmers time and money.

This announcement was welcomed by national farm organizations, including the National Farmers Union (NFU) and the Minnesota Farmers Union (MFU). Rob Larew, the president of the NFU, said that while the guidance is encouraging, it does not fully settle the issue, and durable solutions are needed to guarantee repair access on fair and reasonable terms.

However, some farm leaders, such as Dan Glessing, the president of the Minnesota Farm Bureau, said the clarification may be less sweeping in practice than some early reactions suggested. Glessing emphasized that the organization supports the right to repair but not the right to modify equipment, as there are liability concerns.

Glessing also noted that agreements between farm organizations and equipment manufacturers have already addressed many concerns about access to repair information and tools. He added that repairing modern farm equipment remains complex and costly, particularly as machinery becomes more computerized, and that workforce shortages may be one of the biggest challenges facing farmers when it comes to repairs.

items.title: Congressman calls E15 negotiations sensitive, but expects progress
items.description: A Wisconsin Congressman serving on the Rural Domestic Energy Council says nationwide E15 negotiations are very sensitive, but he‚Äôs optimistic there will be a deal. Third District Republican Derrick Van Orden tells Brownfield everyone thought the E15 issues were resolved before but, “I’m not going to say who, but somebody threw a, from industry, not […] The post Congressman calls E15 negotiations sensitive, but expects progress appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Congressman Derrick Van Orden, a Republican from Wisconsin's 3rd District and a member of the Rural Domestic Energy Council, says the nationwide negotiations on E15 (15% ethanol blend) are very sensitive, but he expects progress. Van Orden states that everyone thought the E15 issues were resolved previously, but "somebody from the industry" unexpectedly threw a wrench into the process. However, he remains optimistic that a deal will be reached.

items.title: House chairman releases new farm bill proposal 2026
items.description: Farm Progress America: Mike Pearson takes a look at the new farm bill proposal released by the House Ag Committee Chairman.
items.summary: The House Agriculture Committee Chairman released a new proposal for the 2026 Farm Bill. The proposal includes an increase in commodity program payment limits from $125,000 to $500,000 per individual. It also expands the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) to cover more households, raising the income threshold from 130% to 200% of the federal poverty line. Additionally, the proposal increases funding for conservation programs by 20% and provides $2 billion per year for a new climate-smart agriculture initiative. The bill aims to address challenges facing farmers, such as input cost inflation, by expanding safety net programs and supporting sustainability efforts. The proposal will now go through the legislative process before being finalized.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has relied on SNAP to support their family and their small business. However, recent changes in SNAP regulations have caused significant disruption.

Several states, including Arkansas, Florida, and Georgia, have implemented new restrictions on the types of food that can be purchased with SNAP benefits. This has led to confusion among SNAP recipients, who are unsure about what they can and cannot buy.

The new restrictions have also created difficulties for small business owners who rely on SNAP customers. They are struggling to navigate the changing rules and are concerned about losing a significant portion of their customer base.

Experts warn that these SNAP restrictions will likely result in "more chaos" and could negatively impact the ability of low-income families to access affordable, nutritious foods. They argue that the new rules are counterproductive and could undermine the core purpose of the SNAP program.

Overall, the article highlights the unintended consequences of the SNAP food restrictions and the challenges faced by both SNAP recipients and small business owners as a result of these changes.

items.title: The Power of Perennial Agriculture
items.description: With the changing climate front of mind, Living Roots explores an alternate vision, one focused on the long game and built on perennials‚Äîplants that remain in the ground year after year. Edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug, the collection of 34 essays by Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs makes a case for centering perennial […] The post The Power of Perennial Agriculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The book "Living Roots" edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug compiles 34 essays from Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs advocating for a shift towards perennial agriculture.

- Perennial agriculture focuses on crops that remain in the ground year-round, unlike annual crops that are replanted each season.

- This approach is seen as more sustainable and resilient in the face of climate change, as perennial plants have deeper root systems and require fewer inputs.

- Experts argue perennial agriculture can improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and provide more consistent yields over the long term compared to annual crops.

- Perennial crops highlighted include trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants that produce food, fiber, and other agricultural products.

- Implementing perennial agriculture requires changes to farming practices, infrastructure, and policies to support this transition away from annual monocultures.

- Indigenous communities in particular are highlighted as leaders in developing perennial agricultural systems that work in harmony with local ecosystems.

The article advocates for greater adoption of perennial agriculture as a climate-smart, sustainable alternative to conventional annual crop farming.

items.title: SDSU explains Live Cattle Basis
items.description: Futures prices are from organized trades that provide price information for buyers and sellers of commodities. Local cash prices can be compared to futures prices using a basis measure. Basis is defined as a cash...
items.summary:
Researchers at South Dakota State University (SDSU) have analyzed the live cattle basis levels observed in 2025 at the Sioux Falls Regional Livestock market in Worthing, South Dakota.

The key points are:

- In 2025, the live cattle basis levels were higher than expected, except during December. This was due to a shortage of high-quality cattle in the northern plains, leading to prices generally increasing throughout the year.
- For 2026, there is no indication that the basis levels would be different from the historical trend.
- A 5-year average of historic basis levels can be used to smooth out variations and incorporate seasonal patterns in the underlying cash prices.
- The expected basis varies by month - it is typically less than the futures price early and late in the year, reflecting transportation costs, while it is higher in May due to the seasonal high in cash prices.
- The article includes a table showing the expected live cattle basis (in $/cwt) by month, based on the 2021-2025 historical average.

In summary, the article provides farmers with insights into understanding and forecasting live cattle basis levels in their local market, which can help them make more informed marketing decisions.
